Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Physiological Ecology of Seasonal Interactions: How Do Wintering Ground Events Constrain Breeding Success in Neotropical Migrants?
Award.AbstractNarration: Migratory birds breed throughout the temperate regions of North America but winter in very different habitats further south. Although 1000 km or more may separate wintering from breeding areas, recent research has revealed that ecological conditions during winter can influence subsequent reproductive success. The major objective of this research is to investigate the underlying physiological factors linking winter events with an individual's ability to breed. The American redstart (Setophaga ruticilla) is an excellent study animal: its ecology and behavior during the wintering and breeding periods have been intensively studied. The degree to which redstarts prepare for breeding, and the factors that influence this, while still on their winter territories will be investigated by analyzing the links between natural and experimentally induced variation in winter habitat quality (food availability), the birds' energetic condition (body mass, fat stores, plasma indicators of energy storage and use), and their breeding status (reproductive hormones) before they leave the wintering grounds. Similar measures of energetic and reproductive condition will also be taken in redstarts as they arrive at the breeding grounds. Stable-carbon isotopes, as markers of winter habitat origin, will be used to link winter and summer events. This research provides greater understanding of how different periods of an individual's life cycle interact to influence reproductive success, will contribute significantly to our understanding of how migrant bird populations are regulated, and will ultimately help resource managers direct conservation efforts more efficiently. The broader impacts of this research include the opportunity to greatly enhance the breadth of professional training of many students, particularly those from underrepresented groups, through its integration of physiology, behavior, and ecology and a variety of lab and field methods, and will strengthen ties with conservation groups in Jamaica.

Endocrine control mechanisms are a critically important aspect of organism function as they mediate an individual’s response to external conditions and, thus, can influence the phenotype-environment interaction. Understanding how such mechanisms regulate behavior is vital to predicting the extent to which organisms are capable of responding to changing environments. For instance, the timing of migration in birds, which is the outcome of an interplay between external cues and internal physiological processes, is of great importance to reproductive fitness. Elucidating aspects of the endocrine system that regulate departure and arrival times is a critical early step in determining the constraints on future adaptation in these populations.

            While migratory birds complete life history stages in different geographical areas, these locations are inextricably linked in terms of an individual’s fitness. Events in one location can carry-over to influence events in subsequent locations in what are termed ‘seasonal interactions’ . These interactions are especially apparent in spring, when migrants find themselves at the intersection of non-breeding, migratory, and breeding life history stages. During this season, birds must continue to maintain the mechanisms that support winter survival while also beginning to prepare for migration that can be thousands of miles long. These processes ultimately can act to ensure arrival at breeding sites, establish breeding territories, and attempt to reproduce. Recent studies in migratory birds have demonstrated that the quality of non-breeding habitat can not only affect an individual’s ability to maintain condition throughout the winter period, but can also influence spring departure and arrival schedules, such that individuals from superior habitats arrive earlier to breed and ultimately have greater reproductive success. While food availability and climate have been implicated as limiting ecological factors in determining departure dates from wintering sites, how the endocrine system may influence these carry-over effects is not well understood.

            Linking the non-breeding, migratory, and breeding stages of the annual cycle is a series of complex physiological changes that facilitate preparation for migration and transition into the breeding state.  While the energetic demands of these changes may conflict, physiological mechanisms that diversify hormone function could enable individuals to meet both of these demands and minimize conflicts. For males of migratory species, the gonadal androgens, such as testosterone are critical in the transition into a breeding state. In addition to reproductive functions,  androgens play an important behavioral role in birds as a regulator of male-male aggression associated with acquiring high quality breeding territories and territory boundary advertisement (i.e. singing behavior). Androgens are also fundamental in the expression of secondary sex traits and courtship behaviors that influence breeding success in birds.
